author: idonteatchips
body: Yes in the USA there are tax prep companies (like Intuit and H&R Block)  that lobby to Congress so they can stay in business and continue making money. It's because of them that US taxes are "complicated" and we need to file them ourselves every year rather than the govt do it for us like other countries do.

author: CD_4M
body:
Filing taxes is easy, with or without Intuit, most people just put precisely zero effort into figuring it out or just enjoy participating in this big “omg taxes so hard” meme for some reason. Unless you’re self employed complaining about how hard taxes are just means you’re either stupid or haven’t even tried to figure it out. Also $6M is a hilariously small lobbying effort. 

You honestly believe filing taxes is so hard that the government needs to step in...? And you also believe the government won’t step in because of $6 million? Come on, man.

author: CD_4M
body: This Reddit take is so annoying. Anyone can file their taxes for free without using Intuit’s software. Why anyone would expect software that makes it 10x easier to be free has always confused me. If you think taxes are too hard without Intuit’s software then complain to the government, not Intuit. They are simply solving a need and rightfully getting paid for their effort.

author: GRaTePHuLDoL
body: Deactivating account and deleting app, what a shame. Don't blame them for taking the payday but these are the type of buyouts I despise and makes me dislike Intuit even more.

author: I_read_it_in_a_book
body: It may be easy for you. The tax filing industry wouldn't exist if it were easy for everyone. And there are a ton of different scenarios to take into account depending on the individual's situation. $6 million THIS YEAR. I haven't done the thorough research, but I'm willing to bet Intuit has spent a fuckload of money lobbying to prevent the government from having their own online portal.

author: swxrice
body: The key is that you have to be self-sustaining. When Intuit started looking to buy CreditKarma, they got audited financials. If CK were unprofitable with no clear path to profitability, Intuit would have just let them die on their own. *Maybe* they would have gotten into a price war to accelerate it, but they certainly wouldn't pay $7B for a failing company. A purchase like that could make sense if the data or other assets were valuable, but TurboTax is still big enough that it's not likely they'll gain anything in those regards from CK.

author: billatq
body: Which was operated by Intuit the last I'd checked.

author: bender_the_offender0
body:
This source basically covers that idea. 

The argument for it is that a large number of people have simple taxes so this would make it easy. The argument against is that for many it doesn’t capture everything and people might assume what the IRS tells you is the correct number. The other argument against is more philosophical in that if people don’t pay attention to their taxes then the government has carte blanche to raise them since people wouldn’t pay attention. In either case there are obvious entrenched interest against this. 

https://www.propublica.org/article/filing-taxes-could-be-free-simple-hr-block-intuit-lobbying-against-it

author: stizzleomnibus1
body: Mint was an amazing tool in 2012 when I started using it, and was great up until Intuit bought it and tried to merge in the "Mint Bills" tool. Shortly after that was the Great Unsynching, where Mint couldn't update most banks. Every time you logged in to your account everything was lit up red. The data became so far out of sync as to be useless. It lingered that way for months because of the complete lack of resources that Intuit put into it. That part eventually got better, but it took so long I'd already moved on to Personal Capital.

author: ZombieElephant
body: I *just* filed my taxes for 2019 with FTUSA after using Turbotax for +5 years. It was fantastic, and I highly recommend it. Intuit is a reprehensible company (as highlighted in the Propublica coverage), and TurboTax is so expensive (all that marketing, I suppose).

author: ElRamenKnight
body:
> They must've felt threatened by CreditKarma's free tax software. They'll probably strip it of all features that aren't included in their free edition (not the FreeFile edition). There's always value in eliminating competition.  

Just yesterday, received an e-mail from Intuit:  

	

> Dear Valued Customer,
>  
> We are writing to notify you of a price increase for TurboTax Online products after February 29, 2020. If you haven't completed or filed your return yet, we encourage you to file your taxes before prices go up. If you have already filed, please disregard this notice and thank you for using TurboTax.

author: kboogie82
body: I have brokerage accounts and a slightly more complicated return wouldn't be free for me cheaper but not free. Hopefully somebody else offers free tax like credit karma suck Intuit bought them.

author: blahblah98
body: Intuit - one of the genuinely evil consumer predatory companies.  I hope Bernie regulates the fuck out of those guys.

author: stone3pole8holly2
body:
They have lost their moral compass by making it difficult to locate their free return website by using misleading URL names and by the misleading text on their web pages. They charge people for returns when the return should be free (as a function of income). They try to convince you to upgrade to a paid version on a more expensive version when it is not necessary.

I've never seen it publically disclosed what they actually do with your tax return data, whether it is prepared on-line or off-line.

Your return has everything on it.

I don't want intuit to have access to my credit info so I deleted my KC account today.

author: WilliamNyeTho

author: autotldr
body:
This is the best tl;dr I could make, [original](https://www.wsj.com/articles/intuit-near-deal-to-buy-credit-karma-for-7-billion-11582433880) reduced by 80%. (I'm a bot)
*****
> Intuit Inc. INTU -1.22% is nearing a deal to buy personal-finance portal Credit Karma Inc. for about $7 billion in cash and stock, in a move that would push the bookkeeping-software giant further into consumer finance, according to people familiar with the matter.

> Credit Karma offers its customers free access to their credit scores and borrowing history, alerts to possible data breaches, credit monitoring and tax preparation and filing.

> Customers in turn receive offers from other companies for credit cards and loans tailored to their credit history, and Credit Karma makes money when customers use those products.


*****
[**Extended Summary**](http://np.reddit.com/r/autotldr/comments/f9g7cl/intuit_buying_credit_karma_is_not_good_news_good/) | [FAQ](http://np.reddit.com/r/autotldr/comments/31b9fm/faq_autotldr_bot/ "Version 2.02, ~470317 tl;drs so far.") | [Feedback](http://np.reddit.com/message/compose?to=%23autotldr "PM's and comments are monitored, constructive feedback is welcome.") | *Top* *keywords*: **Credit**^#1 **Karma**^#2 **Intuit**^#3 **deal**^#4 **Inc.**^#5
